title: What Happened When DataCamp Tried To Cover Up Its CEO’s Sexual Misconduct

last_post.content: Five years later, I still occasionally get pokes on LinkedIn saying, "Hey, you used to work at DataCamp, what can you tell me about them?" My response is, "Their CEO committed sexual assault, they tried to bury the story, he finally stepped aside after an outcry but returned while everyone was distracted by COVID." See https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/daveyalba/datacamp-sexual-harassment-metoo-tech-startup for @daveyalba's excellent summary from 2019 and https://third-bit.com/2019/04/15/an-exchange-with-datacamp/ for a personal addendum.

Five years later, I still occasionally get pokes on LinkedIn saying, "Hey, you used to work at DataCamp, what can you tell me about them?" My response is, "Their CEO committed sexual assault, they tried to bury the story, he finally stepped aside after an outcry but returned while everyone was distracted by COVID." See https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/daveyalba/datacamp-sexual-harassment-metoo-tech-startup for @daveyalba's excellent summary from 2019 and https://third-bit.com/2019/04/15/an-exchange-with-datacamp/ for a personal addendum.

The third report on the R-spatial evolution project has been published. It links back to earlier blogs and presentations, and focusses on work that maintainers of R packages and workflows using rgdal, rgeos and maptools need to put in train now. The first changes will occur in June 2023, and the retiring packages will be archived during October 2023. If you are giving a workshop or tutorial during the Northern hemisphere summer, aim for June. #rspatial @rsbivand

https://r-spatial.org/r/2023/04/10/evolution3.html

last_post.content:
I really enjoyed the challenge of writing this piece for the 50th anniversary of the Xerox Alto.
https://spectrum.ieee.org/xerox-alto
There's still tickets available for PyData Seatltle April 26th-28th https://pydata.org/seattle2023/

👉🏼 „Saying Goodbye to GitHub | Ersei 'n Stuff”
🔗https://ersei.net/en/blog/bye-bye-github
💬 …you too can get programming help with no obligation to give back to anyone!
Harsh words, but good discussion points. Personally I don't think Copilot breeds more lurkers, they are a general problem.

Inspired by Cory Doctorow (@pluralistic) , I've been thinking about the IndieWeb idea of POSSE (Publish on your Own Site, Syndicate Elsewhere, see https://indieweb.org/POSSE) and how to extend the reach of my blog posts. So I'm trying something new and syndicating blog posts to dev.to.

dev.to makes this quite nice with native support a "canonical URL" for posts originally published elsewhere. It's also pretty easy to repost existing content to since it supports Markdown (my posts are written in reStructuredText for my website but can be easily converted to Markdown using pandoc) and future posts can be automatically shared to dev.to via an RSS feed.

So, assuming I don't find any reason to cancel this experiment, you'll be able to read my writing at https://dev.to/pbarker as well as here on Mastodon and on my website.

(originally posted at https://pbarker.dev/posts/2023-04-10/syndication/)

#writing #blog #blogging #indieweb

title: Do you actually need a vector database? | Ethan Rosenthal

last_post.content:
New blog post: Do you actually need a vector database?
https://www.ethanrosenthal.com/2023/04/10/nn-vs-ann/

To go along with the blog post, I made a small repo to benchmark using a "vector DB" (aka approximate nearest neighbors) with "brute-force" nearest neighbors https://github.com/EthanRosenthal/nn-vs-ann

The main takeaway is that the brute-force method takes ~50 milliseconds / 1 million embeddings on my computer, so hopefully those numbers can help you to make a decision on whether you need a vector DB!

New blog post: Do you actually need a vector database?
https://www.ethanrosenthal.com/2023/04/10/nn-vs-ann/

To go along with the blog post, I made a small repo to benchmark using a "vector DB" (aka approximate nearest neighbors) with "brute-force" nearest neighbors https://github.com/EthanRosenthal/nn-vs-ann

The main takeaway is that the brute-force method takes ~50 milliseconds / 1 million embeddings on my computer, so hopefully those numbers can help you to make a decision on whether you need a vector DB!

Basically:

🔹 AI doesn't reliably give useful results, but even if it did
🔹 AI rampantly perpetuates existing harms, but even if it didn't
🔹 AI proponents are not being honest or acting in good faith, but even if they were
🔹 People don't understand the limits of LLMs or how they work, but even if they did
🔹 AI cannot maintain a complex system because it's fundamentally a task of understanding the system, but even if it could

Humans still need opportunity to learn how to make sense of those systems, and we do that by making them. Giving all the work that's most conducive to learning to a computer is selling out our futures. Even if there was some present benefit, which I'm not convinced there is.

https://jenniferplusplus.com/losing-the-imitation-game/

The database also contains "three main attributes – building type, height and construction year – included for respectively 45%, 74%, 24% of the buildings."

More details in today's edition of Data Is Plural: https://www.data-is-plural.com/archive/2023-04-05-edition/

Protect elders from harming themselves! Ban them from watching television! Cuz clearly restricting media access is the key to stopping a mental health crisis in our country.

Instead, these efforts are about asserting control and limiting young people from accessing publics. Satire + seriousness: https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/protect-elders-ban-television-danah-boyd/

I made @nycviewsbot a few years ago for a tutorial I wrote for https://botwiki.org to show how to make a bot that posts random webcam pictures from around a city.

I cringe every time I see this bot post yet another traffic jam.

I finally got around to manually reviewing all NYC webcams and the result is a much better and a more focused celebration of what is still one of the greatest cities.

Hope you'll enjoy this updated version!

#bots #nyc #webcam

This course on parallel programming by @JukkaSuomela at Aalto is absolutely fantastic:

There are a lot of words in his article dancing around what I think is a simple, obvious dilemma for the GOP:

🔹 The GOP base wants hard-core Trump-Kari Lake candidates.

🔹The general electorate doesn't.

So the candidates who win GOP primaries are likely to lose in general elections.

The problem gets worse for the GOP with each election cycle as the electorate grows more diverse, and more of the generation that came to the polls in Wisconsin are eligible to vote.

I recently wrote an intro vignette for the R implementation of `polars`. https://rpolars.github.io/articles/rpolars.html

If you haven't heard of it yet: `polars` is a new-ish data wrangling library, originally written in Rust, but with bindings to several other languages (most notably Python but now R and NodeJS).

Lots to like and very fast.
